column1: #Text=# When Mitigating Bias is Unfair: A Comprehensive Study on the Impact of Bias Mitigation Algorithms
#Text=This repository contains the codebase for "When Mitigating Bias is Unfair: A Comprehensive Study on the Impact of Bias Mitigation Algorithms" (on [Arxiv](https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07185)).

column1: #Text=Most works on the fairness of machine learning systems focus on the blind optimization of common fairness metrics, such as Demographic Parity and Equalized Odds.
#Text=In this paper, we conduct a comparative study of several bias mitigation approaches to investigate their behaviors at a fine grain, the prediction level.
#Text=Our objective is to characterize the differences between fair models obtained with different approaches.
#Text=With comparable performances in fairness and accuracy, are the different bias mitigation approaches impacting a similar number of individuals?
#Text=Do they mitigate bias in a similar way?
#Text=Do they affect the same individuals when debiasing a model?
#Text=Our findings show that bias mitigation approaches differ a lot in their strategies, both in the number of impacted individuals and the populations targeted.
#Text=More surprisingly, we show these results even apply for several runs of the same mitigation approach.
#Text=These findings raise questions about the limitations of the current group fairness metrics, as well as the arbitrariness, hence unfairness, of the whole debiasing process.
#Text=├── fairlearn_int <-- [Fairlearn](https://fairlearn.org/) with slight modifications to allow working with multiple different data structures
#Text=├── notebooks <-- folder containing experiments for each analysed dataset, structured in the following way:
